Crimes.Dispute_Type: Election appeal jurisdiction and procedural fairness
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Jurisdiction of the Appeal Committee and breach of procedural fairness
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicant failed to provide evidence and did not object during hearing
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On the Applicant to demonstrate lack of jurisdiction or breach
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant's failure to raise objections at first opportunity
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Jurisdiction reviewed on reasonableness; procedural fairness on correctness
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Dispute over 2009 by-election as continuation of 2006 General Election
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: No breach of procedural fairness or lack of jurisdiction found
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Evidence from Wilson Appeal, timing of by-election
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Did not object during hearing, failed to present evidence
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of Appeal Committee decision
Crimes.Outcome: Dismissed with costs awarded against Applicant

Crimes.Crime_Name: Corrupt practice in connection with an election
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Election-related corrupt practices
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Challenge to findings of corrupt practices based on 2006 election events
Crimes.Legal_Framework: EPA governing election procedures and appeals
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: No breach of procedural fairness or lack of jurisdiction
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Appeal Committee upheld finding of corrupt practices
Crimes.Jurisdiction: Deemed valid over by-election as continuation of 2006 election
Crimes.Individual_Status_or_Claim: Applicant found guilty of corrupt practices
Crimes.Credibility: Applicant waived claims by not objecting during proceedings

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration admissibility
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Inadmissibility under paragraph 36(1)(c) of the IRPA due to use of fraudulent documents
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), paragraph 36(1)(c), section 133
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly assessed, but document authenticity was key
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Fraudulent passport and driver's license used in the UK
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Use of fraudulent driver's license outside Canada unrelated to entry
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Section 133 protection does not apply to acts unrelated to entering Canada
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Admissibility hearing followed by judicial review
Crimes.Decision_Maker: Immigration Division, Federal Court on judicial review
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Serious criminality under Canadian law (punishable by 10+ years)
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Acts constituting serious criminality outside Canada
Crimes.Application_Factor: Location and purpose of document use
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; Mr. Uppal remains inadmissible
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Use of fraudulent driver's license in the UK

Crimes.Crime_Name: Fraudulent acquisition of a driver's licence
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration admissibility
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Inadmissibility under paragraph 36(1)(c) of the IRPA due to fraudulent acquisition of a driver’s licence
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), paragraph 36(1)(c), section 133
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Document fraud established through evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Fraudulent driver's license obtained in the UK
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Acquisition and use of forged driver's license outside Canada not protected under s. 133
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Act unrelated to entering Canada; no protection under s. 133
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Admissibility hearing followed by judicial review
Crimes.Decision_Maker: Immigration Division, Federal Court on judicial review
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Serious criminality under Canadian law (max. 10-year imprisonment)
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Foreign act equivalent to serious criminality in Canada
Crimes.Application_Factor: Nature and context of document fraud
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; Mr. Uppal remains inadmissible
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Fraudulent acquisition of UK driver's license

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration admissibility
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Inadmissibility under paragraph 36(1)(c) of the IRPA for uttering a forged document
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), paragraph 36(1)(c)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Use of forged documents confirmed
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Fraudulent passport and driver's license used in the UK
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Uttering forged driver's license in the UK, not related to entry into Canada
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: No protection under s. 133 because act was unrelated to entering Canada
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Punishable by at least 10 years imprisonment under Canadian law
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Serious criminality based on foreign conduct
Crimes.Application_Factor: Jurisdiction and intent behind document use
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; Mr. Uppal remains inadmissible
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Uttering forged driver's license in the UK

Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in concluding applicants were not Convention refugees or persons in need of protection
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Credibility_Assessment: Principal applicant’s inconsistent statements undermined credibility
Evidence_Type: Credible evidence of state protection in Peru, evidence regarding Shining Path threats and DINCOTE persecution
Legal_Provision: Lack of state protection, absence of valid internal flight alternative (IFA) under IRPA
Basis_of_Claim: Alleged persecution by Shining Path and Peruvian anti-terrorist police
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Availability of state protection in Peru and reasonable internal flight alternative in Lima
Application_Factor: Credibility, state protection, internal flight alternative
Decision_Outcome: Applicants not recognized as refugees or persons in need of protection
Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court

Dispute_Type: Jurisdictional and constitutional challenge to investigative authority
Legal_Issue: Whether the Information Commissioner has authority to hold an individual in contempt for refusing to answer questions
Governing_Law: Section 36(1)(a) of the Access to Information Act
Evidence_Assessment: Court dismissed motion to strike affidavit evidence
Decision_Outcome: Motion to strike evidence denied; amendment to notice permitted; request to add Attorney General rejected; bifurcation of issues denied
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant (Mr. Rowat) to demonstrate lack of jurisdiction and constitutional violations
Legal_Rule: Section 36(1)(a) empowers the Information Commissioner to investigate and cite for contempt
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness, as applicable to jurisdictional and constitutional questions
Grounds_for_Claim: Lack of Commissioner's jurisdiction, alleged violation of constitutional rights
Outcome_on_Merits: Not decided on merits; procedural rulings made
Key_Evidence_Considered: Affidavit evidence regarding refusal to disclose source of knowledge
Legal_Framework: Access to Information Act, constitutional principles
Defendant_Response: Mr. Rowat challenged jurisdiction and raised constitutional objections
Remedy_Requested: Declarations on jurisdiction and constitutionality, amendment of pleadings, severance of issues
Outcome: Partial procedural success: amendments allowed; other requests denied
Legal_Provision: Section 36(1)(a) of the Access to Information Act

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration and Refugee
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the refusal of the applicant's humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) application for permanent residence was reasonable and procedurally fair
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) and Regulations
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicant provided limited evidence about her situation in Kenya
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Refusal of H&C application upheld
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to provide sufficient evidence to justify exceptional relief
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: No significant credibility issues raised, but lack of evidence weakened claim
Crimes.Legal_Rule: H&C decisions are discretionary; court reviews for reasonableness and procedural fairness, not re-weighing of evidence
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Request for permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Key_Evidence_Considered: Limited evidence on ties to Canada
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Second Secretary analyzed evidence and exercised discretion within legal parameters
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Permanent residence based on H&C grounds
Crimes.Authority: Second Secretary, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada

Crimes.Violation_Type: Non-disclosure of dependent in immigration application
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) and Regulations
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant's mother failed to disclose her as a dependent when applying for permanent residence
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Adult child seeking sponsorship despite non-disclosure
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Mother became permanent resident without disclosing applicant
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Omission constitutes misrepresentation if willful or negligent
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: No interview conducted; no request made by applicant or counsel
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority of Second Secretary to assess H&C exemption
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Sparse evidence on best interests of the child and hardship in Kenya
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No adverse finding, but insufficient proof of exceptional circumstances
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Refusal of H&C application due to bar on sponsorship
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Exemption from sponsorship inadmissibility on H&C grounds
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Discretionary assessment of H&C factors under s.25(1) IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No justification for exemption due to lack of evidence on best interests and hardship
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Second Secretary, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada

Evidence_Assessment: Resemblance in marks starting with 'Timber', downplaying of 'by Wrangler'
Decision_Outcome: Appeal dismissed
Burden_of_Proof: Wrangler failed to prove absence of confusion
Legal_Rule: Assessment of likelihood of confusion based on appearance, sound, or suggested ideas
Grounds_for_Claim: Similarity between 'Timber Creek by Wrangler' and 'Timberland'
Key_Evidence_Considered: Mark similarity, consumer perception, prominence of 'Timber'
Legal_Framework: Trademark registration and opposition under the Trademarks Act
Defendant_Response: Wrangler argued against dissecting the mark
Remedy_Requested: Registration of 'Timber Creek by Wrangler' for footwear
Outcome: Registration denied
Legal_Provision: Sections of the Trademarks Act relating to confusion

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of refugee claim decision
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether judicial review can be granted despite false testimony and omissions
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant found not credible due to inconsistencies and concealment
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Deliberate false testimony and failure to prove counsel incompetence
Crimes.Application_Error: False statements regarding departure date, route, and Swiss residence
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None; new evidence deemed insufficient due to prior misconduct
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Demonstrable injustice due to counsel incompetence required
Crimes.Application_Factor: Blame on former counsel without proof
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: No relief granted, no new hearing ordered

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review involving credibility in refugee proceedings
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether perjury disqualifies applicant from discretionary relief
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: False testimony about travel and residence deemed material
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Judicial review denied
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show justification or error
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Perjury undermines claim and disqualifies from relief
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Allegation of poor legal advice excusing false statements
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Blamed former counsel for false statements
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Certification of question of general importance

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of misrepresentation in asylum process
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether misrepresentation based on counsel’s advice invalidates claim
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant lacked credibility due to deliberate lies
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Refugee protection based on fabricated journey and history
Crimes.Application_Error: False departure date, route, and omission of Switzerland stay
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: New evidence not considered due to prior fraud
Crimes.Application_Factor: Attempt to shift blame to counsel
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: No relief, no further action
Crimes.Document_Fraud: False statements in official refugee claim documents

Legal_Issue: Whether the defendant's Skyplume apparatus infringes claims 1 and 2 of the '163 patent
Evidence_Assessment: Expert evidence was used to assess differences in nozzle bifurcation, diffuser presence, and orientation
Decision_Outcome: Defendant's product does not infringe the '163 patent; patent is valid
Burden_of_Proof: Plaintiff bore the burden of proving infringement
Credibility_Factor: Expert testimony was considered credible and influential
Legal_Rule: Infringement occurs when all essential elements of a patent claim are reproduced
Standard_of_Review: Objective technical and legal comparison of patent claims
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged unauthorized reproduction of patented invention
Key_Evidence_Considered: Design differences in nozzle, diffuser, and orientation; commercial success of the patent
Legal_Framework: Patent Act (Canada); principles of novelty, utility, non-obviousness
Defendant_Response: Denied infringement and counterclaimed for invalidity and unfair trade practices
Evidence_Type: Technical expert reports, product design documentation
Outcome: Plaintiff's claim dismissed; costs awarded to defendant
Authority: Canadian court with jurisdiction over intellectual property matters

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants failed to prove unusual hardship; ties to Canada were insufficient; son's U.S. citizenship noted but not determinative
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Applicants denied refugee status, seeking permanent residence
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of refusal to exempt from visa requirement
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Ties to Canada, family circumstances, son's U.S. citizenship
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to demonstrate unusual, undeserved, or disproportionate hardship
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Refusal of exemption upheld
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Exemption from visa requirement based on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds under IRPA s. 25(1)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No unusual hardship proven; decision within acceptable range of outcomes

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with Immigration and Refugee Protection Act requirements
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refusal of visa exemption on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Unreasonable error in refusal of exemption under IRPA s. 25(1)
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Personal ties to Canada, child’s citizenship, hardship claims
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of proof of unusual or disproportionate hardship
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Son's U.S. citizenship was not considered but deemed immaterial
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds under IRPA s. 25(1)
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Refusal of exemption upheld

Crimes.Crime_Name: Humanitarian and Compassionate application refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refusal of H&C application
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the immigration officer's refusal was reasonable
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Insufficient evidence of hardship, lack of argument regarding son's adjustment in India
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: H&C application refusal upheld
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to demonstrate unusual hardship
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Section 25(1) IRPA allows discretion based on H&C grounds
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Family ties, residency in Canada, child's circumstances
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Officer found no basis for exemption

Legal_Issue: Whether the refusal to grant an exemption based on humanitarian and compassionate grounds violated procedural fairness or natural justice
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 25
Evidence_Assessment: Integration into Canada, risks in Guinea
Decision_Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Credibility_Factor: Officer found no unusual or disproportionate hardship
Legal_Rule: Minister may exempt individuals from visa requirements based on humanitarian and compassionate considerations
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged breach of procedural fairness and natural justice
Outcome_on_Merits: No reviewable errors found; decision upheld
Key_Evidence_Considered: Evidence of integration in Canada, country conditions in Guinea
Defendant_Response: Immigration officer considered all evidence and did not require interview
Outcome: Application dismissed; no certification of serious question of general importance
Legal_Provision: Section 25, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Legal_Issue: Best interests of children in H&C assessment
Evidence_Assessment: Harm to children, potential separation, father's presence
Decision_Outcome: Unreasonable decision
Grounds_for_Claim: Humanitarian and Compassionate grounds, best interests of children
Key_Evidence_Considered: Impact of separation on children, benefits of parental presence
Legal_Framework: Baker v. Canada, Suresh v. Canada
Defendant_Response: Visa Officer denied application based on risk of separation
Outcome: Case remitted to a different visa officer

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Land dispute
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the PRRA Officer erred in dismissing the claim due to lack of evidence and misunderstanding of risks under s. 96 and s. 97
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), sections 96 and 97
Crimes.Outcome: PRRA decision quashed, matter remanded for reconsideration by a different Officer
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer failed to properly assess credibility of new evidence and medical reports
Legal_Provision: s. 97 IRPA (Person in need of protection)
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Well-founded fear of persecution and risk to life due to land dispute and family violence
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Ongoing threats despite cessation of land dispute pursuit
Crimes.Application_Error: Dismissal of new evidence without valid reasoning
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to factual findings
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Connection to Convention grounds or risk under s. 97
Crimes.Application_Factor: Personal vendetta vs. broader persecution analysis
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Unreasonable decision

Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: Death threats linked to familial land dispute
Crimes.Victim_Status: Applicant facing credible threats from relative
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Perpetrator is a Kenyan police officer; history of violence and murders linked to dispute

Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Ongoing and credible risk of harm or death
Crimes.Risk_Type: Personalized threat due to familial conflict with potential state actor involvement

Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: Assault arising from familial land dispute
Crimes.Victim_Status: Individual subjected to physical violence and threats
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Involvement of state actor (police officer cousin); ongoing nature of threats
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Pattern of violent behavior including prior assaults
Crimes.Risk_Type: Personalized, non-state actor with state connections
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Adequate evidence presented but not properly analyzed
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer dismissed evidence without justification

Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Evidence provided but dismissed without proper analysis
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Supportive of PTSD and ongoing danger
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer failed to engage with medical and documentary evidence

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to provide necessaries of life
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Land ownership dispute
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the PRRA Officer properly assessed new evidence and state protection
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Failure to consider new evidence on threats and murders
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Decision found unreasonable, remanded for reconsideration
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show risk, but officer must fairly assess evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Medical report supporting PTSD diagnosis ignored
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Requirement of well-founded fear or risk under IRPA
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution and risk to life due to land dispute
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim rejected initially, later quashed on judicial review
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Refugee protection under Canadian immigration law
Crimes.Defendant_Response: State protection claimed but inadequately analyzed

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Land ownership dispute involving family member who is a police officer
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Officer erred in rejecting new evidence and assessing state protection
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer failed to assess credibility of new threat evidence
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution and risk to life due to personal conflict with state-linked actor
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Involvement of police officer cousin and pattern of violence
Crimes.Application_Error: Improper dismissal of evidence and flawed legal application
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness for facts, correctness for legal interpretation
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Nexus to Convention grounds or risk under s. 97
Crimes.Application_Factor: Personal vendetta versus systemic risk analysis
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Unreasonable decision

Legal_Issue: Did the Board err in failing to perform a separate analysis under section 97 of the IRPA?
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), section 97
Evidence_Assessment: Documentary evidence showing persecution of CUD members
Decision_Outcome: Application for judicial review allowed; case referred back for redetermination under section 97
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to demonstrate risk upon removal
Credibility_Factor: Board accepted the applicant's CUD membership
Legal_Rule: Under section 97 of the IRPA, the Board must assess if removal would subject the claimant to torture, risk to life, or cruel and unusual treatment
Outcome_on_Merits: Section 96 findings upheld; section 97 analysis remanded
Key_Evidence_Considered: Membership in CUD, documentary evidence of persecution
Defendant_Response: Board denied refugee claim without analyzing section 97 risks
Outcome: Case remanded for reassessment under section 97

Legal_Issue: Whether the United States Postal Service (USPS) is entitled to claim official marks under the Canadian Trade-marks Act as a public authority
Governing_Law: Subparagraph 9(1)(n)(iii) of the Canadian Trade-marks Act
Evidence_Assessment: USPS is an independent establishment of the U.S. government and not subject to Canadian governmental control
Decision_Outcome: USPS marks were declared not official; Registrar's decisions were set aside
Burden_of_Proof: On Canada Post Corporation to demonstrate USPS does not qualify as a public authority
Credibility_Factor: Court's determination of control by the Canadian government as key to public authority status
Legal_Rule: Only entities that are public authorities in Canada can claim official marks under subparagraph 9(1)(n)(iii) of the Trade-marks Act
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness in judicial review of administrative decisions
Grounds_for_Claim: USPS is not a Canadian public authority and therefore ineligible to hold official marks
Outcome_on_Merits: Application allowed; USPS cannot claim official marks
Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature and structure of USPS as a U.S. government entity outside Canadian jurisdiction
Legal_Framework: Canadian Trade-marks Act, specifically provisions on official marks and public authorities
Defendant_Response: Registrar of Trademarks had granted official marks to USPS
Evidence_Type: Legal and institutional characterization of foreign governmental entities
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review to set aside the Registrar's decision granting official marks to USPS
Outcome: Application allowed; decisions set aside

Dispute_Type: Subcontracting agreements and ownership representation of the dredge M/V Atchafalaya
Legal_Issue: Whether there is a valid cause of action in rem against the dredge M/V Atchafalaya based on alleged breaches by B+B Dredging Company
Procedural_Stage: Motion under Rule 221 to strike out the claim
Evidence_Assessment: Documents and emails supporting B+B's representation of ownership; ambiguity in Mr. Barlow's conduct
Decision_Outcome: Motion to strike out the claim dismissed
Burden_of_Proof: Defendants failed to show it was plain and obvious that Dragage Verreault lacked a cause of action in rem
Credibility_Factor: Ambiguity in Mr. Barlow's conduct regarding representation of ownership
Legal_Rule: An action in rem requires personal liability (in personam) of the ship owner; without such liability, no in rem jurisdiction exists
Standard_of_Review: Plain and obvious test under Rule 221
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged breaches by B+B Dredging Company and representation of ownership over the dredge
Outcome_on_Merits: Not decided at this stage; case allowed to proceed
Key_Evidence_Considered: Documents, emails, and conduct of Mr. Barlow
Legal_Framework: Federal Courts Rules, principles of admiralty law and in rem jurisdiction
Defendant_Response: Proteus argued lack of contractual relationship or authorization to pledge its credit
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, email correspondence, conduct-based inference
Remedy_Requested: Striking out of the claim for lack of in rem jurisdiction
Outcome: Defendants' motion dismissed; case proceeds with costs awarded to Dragage Verreault
Legal_Provision: Rule 221 of the Federal Courts Rules

Legal_Issue: Is the decision to cancel the applicant's security clearance manifestly unreasonable?
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review under section 18.1 of the Federal Courts Act
Evidence_Assessment: The applicant had a criminal past, including impersonating a police officer. Despite providing additional information, the Advisory Body deemed her a potential risk to civil aviation based on I.4(d) of the Program.
Decision_Outcome: The decision was not manifestly unreasonable therefore, the application for judicial review was dismissed.
Legal_Rule: The applicable standard of review is patent unreasonableness due to the tribunal's expertise and legislative purpose.
Grounds_for_Claim: Criminal charges against the applicant led to the suspension and eventual cancellation of her transportation security clearance.
Outcome_on_Merits: The court rejected the application, upholding the cancellation of the security clearance.
Key_Evidence_Considered: Criminal past involving impersonating a police officer
Risk assessment under I.4(d) of the Program
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Legal_Provision: section 18.1 of the Federal Courts Act

Legal_Issue: Is the decision to cancel the applicant's transportation security clearance manifestly unreasonable?
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review under section 18.1 of the Federal Courts Act
Evidence_Assessment: The applicant had a criminal record for fraud over $5000. Despite providing additional information and obtaining a conditional discharge, the Advisory Body recommended cancellation based on her criminal past and potential risk to civil aviation.
Decision_Outcome: The decision was not manifestly unreasonable the application for judicial review was dismissed.
Legal_Rule: The applicable standard of review is patent unreasonableness, considering the expertise of the tribunal, purpose of the legislation, and nature of the question.
Grounds_for_Claim: Criminal charges against the applicant led to the suspension and eventual cancellation of her transportation security clearance.
Outcome_on_Merits: The court rejected the applicant's challenge, upholding the cancellation of her security clearance.
Defendant_Response: Provided additional information and obtained a conditional discharge
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Legal_Provision: section 18.1 of the Federal Courts Act

Legal_Issue: Is the decision to cancel the applicant's security clearance manifestly unreasonable?
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review under section 18.1 of the Federal Courts Act
Evidence_Assessment: The applicant had a criminal record for fraud over $5000 and was given a conditional discharge. Despite providing additional information, the Advisory Body recommended cancellation based on her criminal past and potential risk to civil aviation.
Decision_Outcome: The decision is not manifestly unreasonable therefore, the application for judicial review is dismissed.
Legal_Rule: The applicable standard of review is patent unreasonableness, considering the expertise of the tribunal, purpose of legislation, and nature of the question.
Grounds_for_Claim: Cancellation of the applicant's transportation security clearance due to her criminal history and perceived risk to civil aviation.
Outcome_on_Merits: The court rejected the application for judicial review, upholding the cancellation of the security clearance.
Legal_Framework: Dr Q v. College of Physicians and Surgeons of British Columbia
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Legal_Provision: section 18.1 of the Federal Courts Act

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Removal order dispute

Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 48(2)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly assessed, but personal circumstances were relevant
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Special circumstances warranting deferral of removal
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonable consideration of special circumstances under s. 48(2)

Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes, due to reporting sexual assault

Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Not challenged; accepted as part of PRRA context

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Removal order dispute
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of refusal to grant stay of removal
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 48(2)
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Pre-removal risk assessment and stay application
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Officer failed to assess relevant personal and health risks

Dispute_Type: Validity of Band Council Resolution and its ratification
Legal_Issue: Whether the Attorney General of Canada is a necessary party in the judicial review
Governing_Law: Rule 303(1)(a) of the Federal Courts Rules
Procedural_Stage: Judicial Review, Motion to Add Respondent
Decision_Outcome: Canada ordered to be added as a respondent, with costs awarded to Canada
Legal_Rule: An applicant must name every person directly affected by the order sought under Rule 303(1)(a)
Grounds_for_Claim: Invalidation of Band Council Resolution could impact Claim 138 Settlement Agreement and Canada's release
Outcome_on_Merits: Canada is directly affected and should be joined as a respondent
Key_Evidence_Considered: Potential impact on settlement agreement and federal interests
Legal_Framework: Federal Courts Rules, administrative law principles on joinder of parties
Defendant_Response: Canada moved to join as a respondent
Remedy_Requested: Addition of Canada as a respondent
Outcome: Motion granted; Canada added as respondent with costs

Legal_Issue: Can the applicant's time for appeal be extended due to administrative errors causing delayed notification of the Registrar's decision?
Evidence_Assessment: Trademark agents' errors led to delayed notification; no fault on applicant's part
Decision_Outcome: Extension of time for appeal granted
Burden_of_Proof: Applicant demonstrated genuine intention to appeal and arguable case
Credibility_Factor: Applicant acted diligently; no delay attributable to them
Legal_Rule: Section 56(1) allows appeal within two months or further time as court may allow
Standard_of_Review: Balance of justice and equitable discretion
Grounds_for_Claim: Administrative error by trademark agents causing late notice
Outcome_on_Merits: Opposition originally rejected by Registrar; appeal not yet decided on merits
Key_Evidence_Considered: Timing of notification, conduct of trademark agents, applicant’s intent
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of correspondence and timelines
Remedy_Requested: Extension of time to file appeal
Outcome: Court allowed extension; applicant to pay respondent's costs and disbursements
Authority: Federal Court (implied from context of appeal under Trade-marks Act)

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee status determination
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the applicants failed to rebut the presumption of state protection in their home country
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant consistently reported incidents despite ongoing violence
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Reports of racially motivated attacks, police inaction
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Systemic discrimination and violence against Roma family
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Cumulative impact of systemic discrimination and lack of effective state protection
Crimes.Application_Error: Equating failure to follow up with police as failure to seek state protection
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Cumulative impact of systemic discrimination and violence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: State protection must be effective, not perfect
Crimes.Application_Factor: Applicant's efforts to report incidents to authorities
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Decision quashed, matter remanded for reconsideration

Crimes.Location_of_Incident: Multiple locations in the Czech Republic
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Repeated assaults over years, racial motivation
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Not applicable – pattern of uninvestigated crimes
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High – ongoing physical violence without intervention
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk due to continued victimization
Crimes.Threat_Source: Host population in the Czech Republic
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient – consistent reporting and credible fear
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Police reports, personal testimony, history of attacks
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Credible – corroborated by pattern and context
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Fear acknowledged as understandable
Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: N/A – case involves asylum determination, not criminal sentencing

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee protection claim based on state inaction
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Inadequate state protection for Roma minority
Crimes.Legal_Framework: International refugee law, domestic immigration law
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Decision quashed, remanded for reconsideration
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Police failure to investigate or protect
Crimes.Perpetrator_Entity: Private actors with state complicity through inaction

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee claim based on ethnically motivated persecution
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Decision quashed and remanded
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: Serious efforts not equivalent to adequate protection
Crimes.Credibility: High – consistent reporting and trauma context

Crimes.Location_of_Incident: Various locations in the Czech Republic
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Repetition, racial motivation, vulnerability of victims
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Fear deemed reasonable and understandable

Crimes.Victim_Status: Roma family subjected to property destruction and threats
Crimes.Location_of_Incident: Multiple locations in the Czech Republic
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Arson used as tool of ethnic intimidation
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Extreme – threat to life and safety
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Incident reports, applicant testimony, relocation history
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Fear justified given trauma and history

Legal_Issue: Whether the Minister met the legal standard for issuing a jeopardy order under s. 225.2(2) of the Income Tax Act
Governing_Law: Income Tax Act, s. 225.2(2) and s. 225.2(8)
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of an ex parte jeopardy order
Evidence_Assessment: Inaccuracies and omissions in CRA's affidavits; misleading characterization of re-assessments; lack of evidence on asset liquidation or relocation intent
Decision_Outcome: Jeopardy order set aside; collection actions halted
Burden_of_Proof: On the Minister to show reasonable grounds for belief that delay would jeopardize collection
Credibility_Factor: CRA affidavits found lacking in credibility due to incomplete and misleading information
Legal_Rule: Section 225.2(2) allows immediate collection if delay jeopardizes tax recovery; full and fair disclosure required in ex parte applications
Standard_of_Review: Reasonable grounds to believe jeopardy to collection
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged risk of taxpayer evading tax through asset liquidation or moving abroad
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed due to insufficient evidence and failure of full disclosure
Key_Evidence_Considered: Mr. Proulx’s intention to appeal assessments; no evidence of plans to flee or dispose of assets
Legal_Framework: Administrative law principles applied to tax enforcement powers
Defendant_Response: Mr. Proulx applied for judicial review challenging the validity of the jeopardy order
Evidence_Type: Affidavit evidence, financial records, communication history
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review and cancellation of the jeopardy order
Outcome: Jeopardy order revoked; CRA prohibited from collection actions unless new circumstances arise
Legal_Provision: s. 225.2(2) and s. 225.2(8), Income Tax Act
Authority: Federal Court (implied from context of judicial review of federal agency action)

Legal_Issue: Whether the risk faced by the applicant is personalized or generalized under IRPA
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, paragraph 97(1)(b)(ii)
Procedural_Stage: Federal Court review of Immigration and Refugee Board decision
Evidence_Assessment: Extortion demands made against the applicant
Decision_Outcome: Application dismissed
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to demonstrate a personalized risk
Legal_Rule: A person is protected if they face a personalized risk not shared by others in their country
Grounds_for_Claim: Risk due to perceived wealth or business ownership in El Salvador
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim failed; risk found to be generalized
Key_Evidence_Considered: Extortion demands, general crime conditions in El Salvador
Outcome: Application dismissed
Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court

Criminality_Severity: Moderate, part of broader pattern of organized crime
Risk_Assessment: High general risk in El Salvador for perceived wealthy individuals
Risk_Nature: Non-personalized, based on status as business owner/perceived wealth
Evidence_Credibility: Not challenged, but context determined risk as generalized
Credibility_Assessment: Credible but insufficient to meet legal threshold

Aggravating_Factors: Ongoing demands, linkage to violent criminal environment
Criminality_Severity: High, within context of systemic extortion in El Salvador
Risk_Assessment: Generalized risk affecting many business owners
Risk_Nature: Based on perceived economic status, not individual targeting
Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient to show victimization, insufficient for personalized risk

Dispute_Type: Procedural dispute over filing of reply affidavit
Legal_Issue: Whether an applicant can file a reply affidavit in the absence of explicit rule authorization
Governing_Law: Federal Court Rules, Rule 321.1, Rule 319, Rule 1603
Decision_Outcome: Reply affidavit dismissed
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to justify filing of supplementary affidavit
Legal_Rule: Supplementary affidavits may be permitted under certain conditions with leave of court
Standard_of_Review: Interpretation of procedural rules and precedents
Grounds_for_Claim: Applicant sought to respond to respondent's affidavits
Outcome_on_Merits: Motion allowed; reply affidavit not permitted
Legal_Framework: Federal Court Rules, case law on affidavit practice
Defendant_Response: Opposed the filing of the reply affidavit as procedurally improper
Outcome: Dismissed; leave to file reply affidavit denied

Decision_Outcome: Denied refugee status
Risk_Nexus: Personalized risk due to reporting gang activity
Outcome: Remanded for redetermination

Risk_Nature: Targeted due to cooperation with authorities

Sub_Crime_Type: Assault in context of gang retaliation
Risk_Nature: Targeted due to cooperation with authorities
Targeted due to resistance and reporting

Violation_Type: Refugee claim based on lack of credibility
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, subsection 72(1)
Application_Facts: Applicants claimed fear of reprisals from family and authorities in Nigeria
Misrepresentation_Element: Credibility issues due to contradictions and implausibilities in claims
Evidence_Used: Testimony and evidence presented to the Board
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Contradictions and implausibilities in Applicants' claims
Credibility_Assessment: Board found Applicants not credible; assessment upheld as reasonable
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claims rejected
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Decision_Rationale: Board's decision fell within a range of acceptable outcomes based on facts and law

Application_Facts: Applicants sought refugee protection after alleged persecution by FARC in Colombia
Procedural_Issue: Board failed to make clear findings on father's kidnapping and applicant's subjective fear
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Uncertainty regarding father's kidnapping, lack of clarity on credibility grounds
Credibility_Assessment: Board's credibility findings questioned due to applicant's inaction in the U.S. and lack of clear findings on fear and kidnapping
Decision_Outcome: Board's decision set aside
Outcome: Remitted for reconsideration
Decision_Rationale: Credibility findings were unreasonable due to insufficient justification and unclear conclusions

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Dispute over removal of Chief and Councillors by Custom Council
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Nelson Respondents' actions constitute obstruction of justice by undermining the legitimate authority of the Custom Council and creating a fake resolution?
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review application under Federal Courts Act
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Analysis of evidence and legal arguments presented by parties
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Court declared the removals valid, denied legitimacy of fake resolution, and ordered costs against Nelson Respondents
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On the party challenging the Custom Council’s authority
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Nelson Respondents disregarded governance rules and caused confusion
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Obstruction of justice involves interfering with the administration of justice or lawful processes
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness and correctness as applicable to administrative decisions
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Fabrication of a false resolution to reinstate removed officials
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Nelson Respondents' actions qualify as obstruction of justice
Crimes.Legal_Framework: RRAFN Constitution, Election Act, Federal Courts Act
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Attempted to retain power via fabricated resolution
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial declaration and enforcement of removal

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Dispute over legitimacy of Nelson Respondents after removal
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Court should grant declaratory and quo warranto relief to confirm the removal of Nelson Respondents as Chief and Councillors
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review application under Federal Courts Act subsection 18.1
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Affidavits, cross-examinations, and legal arguments analyzed
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Court granted declaratory and quo warranto relief, confirming removal and awarding costs
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to prove unlawful holding of office
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Nelson Respondents refused to accept lawful removal
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Quo warranto applies if office is public, exercised, created by law, not dismissible at will, no acquiescence, and plaintiff has genuine interest
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Unlawful retention of office after valid removal
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Removal confirmed; Nelson Respondents ceased holding office
Crimes.Legal_Framework: RRAFN Constitution, Election Act, Federal Courts Act
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Refused to vacate office and fabricated authority
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Declaratory judgment and quo warranto order
Crimes.Outcome: Positions declared vacant, Henry Respondents confirmed, costs on solicitor-client basis
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Federal Courts Act s. 18.1, RRAFN Constitution

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Dispute over legitimacy of Terrance Nelson's position following removal
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can the Court issue a declaration and quo warranto order to remove the Nelson Respondents from their positions as Chief and Councillors?
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review application under Federal Courts Act involving declarations and quo warranto orders
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Oral arguments and affidavits evaluated for truthfulness and compliance
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Court declared removal valid and issued quo warranto order
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Clear and convincing evidence of unlawful occupation of office
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Nelson Respondents knowingly disregarded governance rules
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Quo warranto applies when individual unlawfully holds public office meeting specific criteria
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Correctness for legal determinations of office validity
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Holding office after lawful removal and fabrication of authority
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Nelson Respondents found to be unlawfully holding office
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Affidavits, fake resolution, conduct after removal
Crimes.Legal_Framework: RRAFN Constitution, Election Act, Federal Courts Act
Crimes.Outcome: Officeholders removed, legitimacy transferred to Henry Respondents
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Federal Courts Act, RRAFN Election Act

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Dispute over removal of Chief and Council leading to creation of fake resolution
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the Nelson Respondents fraudulently misrepresent their authority as Chief and Council after being removed by Custom Council?
Crimes.Outcome: Court confirmed removal, declared Henry Respondents legitimate, costs awarded
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Nelson Respondents acted knowingly and deceptively
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Common law of fraudulent misrepresentation, RRAFN laws
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: False representation of ongoing authority after removal
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Intent to deceive and retain power unlawfully
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review under Federal Courts Act
Crimes.Application_Error: Creation of unauthorized resolution purporting to reverse removal
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Objective standard of whether representations were false and misleading
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None noted – court relied on clear documentary falsity
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Fraudulent misrepresentation requires false statement, knowledge of falsity, intent to deceive, and resulting harm
Crimes.Application_Factor: Public reliance on official status and disruption caused
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Misrepresentation established; removal upheld
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness for administrative action, correctness for legal interpretation

Crimes.Crime_Name: Breach of trust by a public official
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Financial mismanagement and refusal to cooperate with audits
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can the Court declare that the Nelson Respondents ceased to hold office and prevent them from holding themselves out as Chief and Council?
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review application under Federal Courts Act
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Affidavits and cross-examinations reviewed for misconduct
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Court declares Nelson Respondents ceased to hold office, awards costs
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On party alleging breach of fiduciary duty
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Persistent defiance of lawful authority and court rulings
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Public officials owe a fiduciary duty to act in the community’s interest
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Correctness for legal questions, reasonableness for factual findings
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Misuse of position, financial mismanagement, refusal to comply with oversight
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Breach of trust established due to misconduct and defiance
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Audit refusals, fake resolution, public statements
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Attempted to override removal through illegitimate means
Crimes.Outcome: Legitimacy transferred to Henry Respondents, sanctions imposed
Crimes.Legal_Provision: RRAFN Constitution, principles of public trust

Violation_Type: Refugee claim based on lack of well-founded fear of persecution
Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 96 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed persecution in Sri Lanka due to Tamil ethnicity; Board found no credible evidence linking fear to race or political opinion; incidents involved authorities and post-war extortion unrelated to Convention grounds
Procedural_Issue: Credibility assessment, linkage of evidence to Convention grounds
Evidence_Used: Applicant's testimony, encounters with authorities, context of post-war Sri Lanka
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible evidence connecting experiences to race or political opinion
Credibility_Assessment: Board found applicant's fear not credible or insufficiently linked to protected grounds
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim denied by the Refugee Protection Division
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of the Board's decision
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of the denial and granting of refugee protection
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution under Section 96
Decision_Rationale: No evidence established a link between the applicant's experiences and persecution based on race, religion, nationality, political opinion, or social group; incidents were attributed to general law enforcement or criminal activity
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada (IRB), Federal Court

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 96, Section 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: HIV-positive individual returning to Nigeria; potential risks upon return; officer failed to assess present and prospective risks
Procedural_Issue: PRRA Officer selectively used evidence, ignored documentation, failed to conduct proper risk assessment
Evidence_Used: Documentation on HIV-related risks in Nigeria
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to consider relevant evidence on HIV risks in Nigeria
Credibility_Assessment: Officer's credibility assessment found unreasonable due to selective use of evidence
Decision_Outcome: PRRA and H&C decisions found unreasonable
Outcome: Decisions set aside; case remanded for redetermination by a different PRRA Officer
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of PRRA and H&C decisions
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of PRRA and H&C applications
Decision_Rationale: Officer did not reasonably evaluate evidence regarding risks under IRPA sections 96 and 97

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 96, Section 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed fear of persecution as a Hindu woman in Bangladesh due to religious-based violence
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of Pre-Removal Risk Assessment decision based on new evidence
Evidence_Used: Evidence of violence against Hindus in Bangladesh
Credibility_Assessment: Officer found applicant's evidence lacked credibility and specificity to establish personal risk
Decision_Outcome: Pre-Removal Risk Assessment Officer's decision upheld
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Relief_Sought: Stay of removal, recognition of risk under IRPA
Legal_Standard_Applied: Personalized risk or generalized oppression rising to level of harm engaging IRPA protection
Decision_Rationale: Officer reasonably concluded no personal risk or sufficient generalized oppression; decision did not misapply legal test

Crimes.Application_Facts: Nabiloo was sentenced to over two years for drug possession; appeal of conviction was pending.
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Subject to deportation due to inadmissibility
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Appeal to IAD dismissed due to lack of jurisdiction
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: IAD lacked jurisdiction under s. 64(2) IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD dismissed appeal; Federal Court dismissed judicial review
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious criminality based on imposed sentence
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: 'Punished' refers to the sentence imposed, not the outcome of a pending appeal

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Deportation based on serious criminality
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether s. 64(2) IRPA bars appeal during criminal appeal
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Imposed sentence of over two years considered sufficient
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD appeal dismissed; judicial review denied
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On claimant to establish eligibility for appeal
Crimes.Legal_Rule: s. 64(2) IRPA applies if sentence is at least two years
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Challenge to IAD's lack of jurisdiction
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA provisions on inadmissibility and appeals
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Argued punishment not final due to pending appeal

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Inadmissibility due to serious criminality
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD lacked jurisdiction; Federal Court dismissed application
Crimes.Applicant_Criminal_Background: Convicted of drug offenses with three-year sentence
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Sentence of three years triggers s. 64(2) IRPA bar

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to disclose dependent child under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the IAD commit a reviewable error in dismissing the applicant's appeal based on misrepresentation?
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of IAD's Removal Order decision
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicant did not disclose marriage or dependent son during visa application and entry
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD's decision was reasonable and within acceptable outcomes
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Omission found to be intentional and serious
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Under IRPA, failure to disclose a dependent child constitutes misrepresentation if it induces an error in immigration processing
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Misrepresentation due to non-disclosure of family members
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Non-disclosure of marriage and dependent child
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA, subsection 18.1(4) of the Federal Courts Act
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA - Failure to disclose dependent child

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of IAD's decision on credibility and humanitarian grounds
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the IAD commit a reviewable error under subsection 18.1(4) of the Federal Courts Act?
Crimes.Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed, Removal Order upheld
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's non-disclosure was found not credible by the IAD
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Visa application records, family status documentation
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Failure to disclose spouse and dependent son leading to erroneous visa issuance
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Seriousness of misrepresentation and lack of credibility
Crimes.Application_Error: Permanent resident visa issued erroneously due to incomplete information
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness of IAD's factual and credibility findings
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to IAD decisions
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD's decision upheld as reasonable

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Legal_Provision_Violated: subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Principal applicant claimed refugee status due to persecution by a Mexican army officer but provided inconsistent narratives regarding pregnancies, her relationship with the officer, and visits to the U.S.
Misrepresentation_Element: Inconsistent narratives presented by the applicant
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of the RPD decision
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Contradictions in the applicant's accounts of key events
Credibility_Assessment: RPD found the applicant not credible due to inconsistencies; court upheld this assessment as reasonable
Decision_Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed
Outcome: RPD's credibility finding upheld
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of RPD's negative credibility determination
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of RPD decision and referral back for reconsideration
Decision_Rationale: The RPD's credibility assessment was based on identifiable contradictions in the applicant's testimony, and such findings are entitled to deference under the reasonableness standard.

Application_Facts: Applicant is an adopted U.S. citizen who applied for Canadian citizenship based on adoption by Canadian parents; application was converted to a discretionary process under subsection 5(4) without clear notification
Procedural_Issue: Lack of clear notification regarding conversion to subsection 5(4) discretionary process
Evidence_Used: Minister’s assessment of the 'totality of circumstances'
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to elaborate on grounds for refusal
Decision_Outcome: Minister’s decision upheld
Outcome: Judicial review dismissed with costs to the respondent
Relief_Sought: Overturning of Minister’s refusal of citizenship application
Remedy_Sought: Declaration that the decision violated procedural fairness or was unreasonable
Decision_Rationale: The Minister had discretionary authority under subsection 5(4); the decision was found to be reasonable and did not breach procedural fairness despite limited explanation
Authority_Responsible: Minister of Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa, arrested twice, failed to report for removal, application for landing delayed and unverified
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to report for removal, delay in application processing
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Arrest records, removal order documentation, family ties information
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of proof of irreparable harm
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Questionable due to evasion behavior
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Motion for stay denied
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review and temporary relief from removal
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Irreparable harm and balance of convenience
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No serious jeopardy to life or safety shown; balance of convenience favors enforcement of immigration laws

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration misrepresentation and stay of removal
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether irreparable harm exists to justify a stay of deportation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Low, due to failure to comply with reporting requirements and change of address without notification
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds, family hardship
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of irreparable harm and non-compliance with removal obligations
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review and motion for stay
Crimes.Application_Error: Delayed and incomplete application for landing
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Serious jeopardy to life or safety required for irreparable harm
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None; court considered all evidence but found insufficient weight
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Irreparable harm and balance of convenience
Crimes.Application_Factor: Family separation and financial support claims
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Stay denied

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with removal order
Crimes.Application_Facts: Failed to report for removal in 1996, remained illegally, applied for humanitarian landing with processing delays
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Removed person not complying with departure obligation
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Removal order, arrest records, application for landing
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No evidence of irreparable harm beyond family separation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Undermined by failure to report and prolonged illegal stay
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Motion for stay denied
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of deportation pending humanitarian application
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Suspension of removal based on hardship
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Irreparable harm and balance of convenience
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No demonstration of serious jeopardy; public interest in enforcing removal orders prevails
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Canada Border Services Agency, Federal Court

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Credibility assessment in refugee claim
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the RAD erred in confirming the RPD's credibility findings
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed, matter referred back for redetermination
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant deemed non-credible due to discrepancies in visa application and testimony
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Refugee status due to domestic violence
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Discrepancies between visa application and refugee claim
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Lack of independent analysis by RAD
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Independent assessment with deference to RPD if justified
Crimes.Application_Factor: Domestic violence as basis for persecution
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Appeal dismissed by RAD, overturned on judicial review

Crimes.Crime_Name: Providing false or misleading information to a visa officer
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Credibility of applicant in refugee claim
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether RAD failed to conduct independent assessment of credibility
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed, case remanded for redetermination
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Credibility challenged due to inconsistencies between visa application and testimony
Crimes.Application_Error: False or misleading information provided in visa application
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: RAD relied solely on RPD findings without re-evaluation
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard with duty of independent analysis
Crimes.Application_Factor: History of domestic violence and fear of return
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: RAD decision set aside, new panel to reassess

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Credibility and authenticity of submitted documents
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether RAD properly assessed credibility based on document discrepancies
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review granted, matter referred for redetermination
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility finding based on inconsistent claims
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Written visa application, refugee claim documentation
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Inconsistencies between visa and refugee applications
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Refugee appeal and federal court review
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Duty of RAD to independently assess evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Failure by RAD to analyze discrepancies independently
Crimes.Application_Factor: Fear of harm upon return due to gender-based persecution
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Appeal dismissed then quashed on review

Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Personalized risk claimed, assessed as generalized by Board
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Reasonable and consistent
Crimes.Legal_Provision: s. 97(1)(b) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Personalized risk claimed, assessed as generalized by Board
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Reasonable and consistent
Crimes.Legal_Provision: s. 97(1)(b) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Crimes.Violation_Type: Abuse of power by state officials
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants victimized by police; claim of lack of state protection
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Scope of Board's interpretation of personalized risk
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board failed to adequately consider targeted nature of risk
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicants found credible
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim initially rejected
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Risk was not generalized given repeated targeting by police

Application_Facts: Applicant was absent for 330 days, falling short by 37 days of the 1,095-day requirement within four years prior to application
Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant with minimum physical presence requirement
Procedural_Issue: Insufficient reasons provided by Citizenship Judge; failure to clarify which test (physical presence or quality of attachment) was applied
Evidence_Used: Documentation submitted by applicant regarding residency and absences
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of clarity in judicial assessment of evidence; request for additional documentation without explanation
Decision_Outcome: Application initially rejected by Citizenship Judge
Outcome: Appeal allowed; decision set aside
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of citizenship application refusal
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration of application by another Citizenship Judge
Legal_Standard_Applied: 1,095 days of physical presence in Canada within four years preceding application; potential application of 'quality of attachment' test
Decision_Rationale: Judge erred by failing to clearly identify the legal test used and provide adequate reasons for decision
Authority_Responsible: Citizenship Commission (via Citizenship Judge), subject to Federal Court review

Application_Facts: Ms. De Torres Mendoza claimed persecution due to her involvement in a corruption investigation; she feared persecution by political rivals after her uncle's murder and sought refugee protection in Canada.
Procedural_Issue: The RPD rejected her claim based on credibility concerns; application for judicial review argued insufficient reasons and unreasonable credibility findings.
Evidence_Used: Testimony of Ms. De Torres Mendoza
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Inconsistencies in testimony cited by RPD as basis for credibility concerns
Credibility_Assessment: RPD found testimony lacked credibility due to inconsistencies; court found the assessment reasonable.
Decision_Outcome: RPD rejected the refugee protection claim
Outcome: Federal Court dismissed the application for judicial review
Relief_Sought: Overturning of RPD's decision and granting of refugee protection
Legal_Standard_Applied: Clear, precise, and intelligible reasons required from RPD; credibility assessments must be reasonable and based on relevant factors
Decision_Rationale: RPD's reasons were adequate and credibility assessment was reasonable

Violation_Type: Failure to Consider Grounds for Protection
Application_Facts: Applicants claimed a well-founded fear of persecution due to past employment; inconsistencies in testimony were found by the Officer.
Claimant_Status: Applicants for permanent residence under the Convention refugees abroad class
Procedural_Issue: Alleged failure to consider all evidence and grounds for protection
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to substantiate claims related to risks from past employment
Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility finding based on inconsistent testimony
Decision_Outcome: Rejection of refugee status and permanent residence application
Outcome: Application dismissed; no reviewable error found
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of immigration officer's decision
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of negative credibility assessment and reconsideration of protection claim
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Decision_Rationale: Officer reasonably assessed credibility and appropriately explored the basis for the Applicants' fears

Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical residency requirement
Legal_Provision_Violated: Residency requirement under the Citizenship Act – three out of four years (1,095 days)
Application_Facts: Dr. Udwadia was physically present in Canada for only 717 days during the four-year period preceding the application
Procedural_Issue: Citizenship judge failed to determine when residence was established; applied subjective test incorrectly
Evidence_Used: Record of Dr. Udwadia's physical presence in Canada (717 days)
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of analysis on establishment of residence despite insufficient physical presence
Decision_Outcome: Appeal allowed; citizenship grant overturned
Outcome: Dr. Udwadia must reapply for citizenship
Relief_Sought: Minister sought judicial review and overturning of citizenship grant
Legal_Standard_Applied: Two-step test for residency: (1) establishment of residence in Canada, (2) minimum 1,095 days of physical presence
Decision_Rationale: The citizenship judge’s decision was unreasonable because Dr. Udwadia did not meet the statutory residency requirement and the judge failed to properly apply the legal test
